skill.name: geopandas
skill.description: Python library for working with geospatial vector data including shapefiles, GeoJSON, and GeoPackage files. Use when working with geographic data for spatial analysis, geometric operations, coordinate transformations, spatial joins, overlay operations, choropleth mapping, or any task involving reading/writing/analyzing vector geographic data. Supports PostGIS databases, interactive maps, and integration with matplotlib/folium/cartopy. Use for tasks like buffer analysis, spatial joins between datasets, dissolving boundaries, clipping data, calculating areas/distances, reprojecting coordinate systems, creating maps, or converting between spatial file formats.
skill.summary: Work with geospatial vector data for spatial analysis, geometric operations, and coordinate transformations
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only repository for geopandas library. All 193 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The analyzer misinterprets Python code examples in markdown documentation as shell/Ruby backtick execution, EPSG codes as weak crypto, and standard file I/O as system reconnaissance. No executable code exists.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Line 7 contains 'CRS information is stored as pyproj.CRS objects' - no backtick execution. The analyzer misinterprets Python method calls like pyproj.CRS as shell commands.
Line 15 shows 'uv pip install geopandas' - this is a documentation example of package installation, not actual command execution. No backticks present.
The analyzer misinterprets EPSG codes like 'EPSG:4326' as weak cryptographic algorithms. These are coordinate reference system identifiers used for geospatial positioning, not crypto.
Line 122 shows 'gdf.geometry.centroid' - a legitimate geospatial operation to calculate geometry centroids, not system reconnaissance.
Line 16 contains 'https://example.com/data.geojson' - an example URL in documentation demonstrating URL reading capability. Not malicious exfiltration.

content.value_statement: Process and analyze geographic data including shapefiles, GeoJSON, and GeoPackage files. Perform spatial joins, geometric operations, coordinate transformations, and create choropleth maps with the geopandas library.
actual_capabilities: Read and write spatial data formats including Shapefile, GeoJSON, GeoPackage, and Parquet
Perform geometric operations such as buffer, simplify, centroid, and convex hull
Execute spatial joins using predicates like intersects, contains, within, and nearest
Manage coordinate reference systems including reprojection and CRS transformation
Create choropleth maps and interactive visualizations with matplotlib and folium
limitations: Does not support raster data formats (use rasterio or GDAL for raster operations)
Requires explicit CRS management for accurate area and distance calculations
Large datasets may require spatial indexing and filtering for performance

use_cases.title: Analyze zoning boundaries
use_cases.description: Process parcel data, perform spatial joins with census tracts, and create density maps

use_cases.title: Study habitat overlap
use_cases.description: Overlay species range polygons, calculate intersection areas, and dissolve administrative boundaries

use_cases.title: Find nearby facilities
use_cases.description: Match customer addresses to store locations using nearest neighbor spatial joins

prompt_templates.title: Read spatial data
prompt_templates.prompt: Read a shapefile called neighborhoods.shp and display the first 5 rows with their geometry types and CRS

prompt_templates.title: Reproject coordinates
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert a GeoDataFrame from EPSG:4326 to EPSG:3857 and calculate the area of each polygon in square meters

prompt_templates.title: Perform spatial join
prompt_templates.prompt: Join crime data points to police district polygons using a within predicate, then count crimes per district

prompt_templates.title: Create choropleth map
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a choropleth map showing population density by county using a divergent color scheme and add a legend

output_examples.input: Read a GeoJSON file of city parks and find which parks are within 500 meters of a transit station
output: ‚Ä¢ Station proximity: Central Station (4 parks), North Station (3 parks), East Station (2 parks)

best_practices: Always check CRS before performing spatial operations and reproject to a projected CRS for accurate measurements
Use spatial indexes and filter during read operations to improve performance with large datasets
Validate geometries with .is_valid before operations and repair invalid geometries using .buffer(0)
anti_patterns: Do not calculate area or distance using geographic CRS (EPSG:4326) - results will be meaningless
Do not skip CRS validation - missing or incorrect CRS leads to spatially incorrect results
Do not perform spatial joins on datasets with different coordinate reference systems

faq.question: What file formats does geopandas support?
faq.answer: Geopandas reads Shapefile, GeoJSON, GeoPackage, KML, Parquet, Feather, and PostGIS databases.

faq.question: How do I convert between coordinate systems?
faq.answer: Use gdf.to_crs('EPSG:3857') to reproject. Always check gdf.crs first to verify the current CRS.

faq.question: What is the difference between spatial join types?
faq.answer: intersects finds overlapping geometries, within finds geometries completely inside, contains finds geometries completely surrounding, nearest finds closest geometries.

faq.question: Why are my area calculations wrong?
faq.answer: You are likely using a geographic CRS (degrees) instead of a projected CRS (meters). Reproject to UTM or equal-area projection first.

faq.question: How do I filter data during read?
faq.answer: Use bbox parameter for bounding box filtering, rows parameter for row limits, columns parameter for specific columns, and where for SQL filtering.

faq.question: Does geopandas support 3D geometries?
faq.answer: Geopandas supports Z coordinates but many operations only work with 2D geometries. Check with gdf.has_z to verify Z values.
